highlights_secondary: Nevertheless, Korean leaders knew they needed to act. One reason? The Wokou were a significant threat to the country's profitable maritime trade. Losing these valuable trade alliances devastated the Korean economy.

highlights_secondary: Though generative AI has the capability to enhance non-player characters, this technology doesn't come without risks. When creating adaptable NPCs, game designers run the risk of losing control of a game's background narrative. Julian Togelius, an associate professor at New York University who researches AI and games, told CNN, "[AI-powered NPCs] may say stuff that is game-breaking or rude or breaks immersion." This could not only expose players to inappropriate or unnecessary commentary, but it could also detract from a player's gameplay experience if the NPCs say something that isn't related to the game's narrative. This means that when game developers are designing AI-powered NPCs, they must ensure that the characters are programmed in a way that prevents them from becoming too unpredictable and distractive.

highlights_secondary: Though generative AI has the capability to enhance non-player characters, this technology doesn't come without risks. When creating adaptable NPCs, game designers run the risk of losing control of a game's background narrative. Julian Togelius, an associate professor at New York University who researches AI and games, told CNN, "[AI-powered NPCs] may say stuff that is game-breaking or rude or breaks immersion." This could not only expose players to inappropriate or unnecessary commentary, but it could also detract from a player's gameplay experience if the NPCs say something that isn't related to the game's narrative. This means that when game developers are designing AI-powered NPCs, they must ensure that the characters are programmed in a way that prevents them from becoming too unpredictable and distractive.

highlights_secondary: When paired with generative AI, game designers think that they could make non-player characters seem more realistic. For instance, generative AI could give NPCs a greater variety of dialogue than these characters typically have. Instead of programming NPCs with the traditional scripted and repetitive lines, generative AI would allow these characters to respond to players based on their actions—and in some cases, based on what players say to them. This is due to generative AI enabling NPC algorithms to be adaptable rather than static, or fixed. For example, if a player made their character run into a building's wall, NPCs would be able to yell out phrases like "look out!" or "I think you're going the wrong way!" Traditional NPCs, however, wouldn't be able to respond unless they had been specifically programmed to.

highlights_secondary:
When paired with generative AI, game designers think that they could make non-player characters seem more realistic. For instance, generative AI could give NPCs a greater variety of dialogue than these characters typically have. Instead of programming NPCs with the traditional scripted and repetitive lines, generative AI would allow these characters to respond to players based on their actions—and in some cases, based on what players say to them. This is due to generative AI enabling NPC algorithms to be adaptable rather than static, or fixed. For example, if a player made their character run into a building's wall, NPCs would be able to yell out phrases like "look out!" or "I think you're going the wrong way!" Along with improved dialogue, generative AI would also allow NPCs to make more natural movements. This technology would give programmers the ability to pair words with gestures (body movements). This would look like NPCs having facial expressions and body gestures that match the tone and mood of what they're saying. So, an NPC wouldn't only be able to yell "look out!," it would also emote and move realistically in response to players' actions.

highlights_secondary: The AI companies argue that they haven’t broken any copyright laws. They claim that using artwork to train AI models counts as “fair use”—an exception in copyright law. Fair use allows for the use of copyrighted material without permission when it is transformed into something completely different than the original. According to the AI companies, the image generators don’t simply create copies of the original artists’ work. Instead, the AI analyzes billions of labeled images, finds patterns in the data, and then uses this information to create images that have never existed before. In a court filing, Stability AI said that their program creates “entirely new and unique images” and that these images rarely, if ever, look like the ones used for training.

To successfully expel the Italian forces, Menelik looked for ways to unite regional Ethiopian rulers behind the war effort. highlights_secondary:
To successfully expel the Italian forces, Menelik looked for ways to unite regional Ethiopian rulers behind the war effort. He strengthened the relationships between these leaders by negotiating new strategic agreements. Menelik highlighted their shared heritage and used this common ground to bring local rulers together.

The emperor also issued a rousing call to arms in September 1895 to expand the Ethiopian military. In just two months, Menelik mobilized an army of over 100,000 Ethiopians. Men from across the country, including many skilled warriors, volunteered to fight. Women also played a crucial role by providing the necessary food and supplies; some planned and led in the battle as well.

highlights_secondary:
No matter what the French did, the rats always came back. It wasn't long before they seemed to be everywhere in Hanoi, France's colonial capital in Vietnam.
Then there were the rats nobody saw—at least, not until it was too late. Many scampered through the underground sewer system into colonial homes where they emerged, sopping wet and sniffling, in residents' toilet bowls.
Colonial French officials decided to pay Vietnamese laborers to catch the pests: one cent for every tail–proof of a successful hunt.
The tails piled up. The payments went out. But—like always—the rats came back.

highlights_secondary: Why were the French concerned about rats in Vietnam? The sight of these pests running free in Hanoi was considered further proof that France's "civilizing mission" was necessary. During the 19th and 20th centuries, French leaders justified colonialism by claiming their culture was better than that of the people they colonized. These beliefs about France's superiority fueled "civilizing missions" around the world: according to French leaders, imposing French values made colonial subjects more "civilized" and, as a result, better off.

highlights_secondary: For Russian leaders in the mid-19th century, Siberia’s landscapes were more than just beautiful scenery. Underneath the vast and varied terrain, there was a gold mine—literally. highlights_secondary: Workers decided to petition the government when these massive protests failed. Led by Father Georgy Gapon, a local Russian Orthodox priest and head of St. Petersburg’s Assembly of Russian Factory Workers union, they drafted a letter outlining their demands. Then, on January 22, 1905, workers and their families marched toward the imperial palace, urging the tsar to listen to their pleas. However, the tsar was not there—and the marchers never made it to the gates. Troops opened fire as they approached, killing about 200 men, women, and children.

highlights_secondary: In 1904, when four Putilov Mill workers were fired for asking for better wages and shorter hours, frustrations reached an all-time high. Groups across Russia had illegally led protests against actions like these for decades without success; nevertheless, Putilov Mill workers decided to organize a strike. More than 10,000 employees joined the protest, but mill owners continued to ignore their demands. In solidarity, over 150,000 other workers across St. Petersburg went on strike, leading to electricity shortages and delayed newspaper distribution.

highlights_secondary: Additionally, Russian industrial workers lacked political representation to help them challenge these anti-union laws or improve their workplaces. Since Russia was an absolute monarchy, all power resided with the tsar. This meant that there was no representative assembly or constitution to assist the workers and promote their needs.

label: Label_2

feedback_primary:

feedback_secondary:
Keep revising! Try to be even more specific.

What kept the industrial workers from striking or forming unions? Read the highlighted text for ideas.
highlights_secondary: Russian workers had limited ways to address the issues they faced. Despite resistance from elites and business owners, workers in other parts of Europe were able to form labor unions to advocate for better working conditions. These groups also helped protest unfair treatment through collective actions like strikes. By contrast, the Russian government made both labor unions and strikes illegal, and protesters often faced imprisonment, violence, or worse. Many leaders feared that expanding labor rights would threaten their power and limit profits from newly-booming industries.

highlights_secondary: In order to get the data that they need, the CETI team is working on some unique solutions: for example, they’re using drones to attach specially-designed listening devices to whales. Once a device is attached to a whale using suction cups, it will record the whale for up to 8 hours, after which it will come loose and float to the surface where researchers can retrieve it. They’re also placing listening devices on the seafloor to capture whale clicks thousands of feet below the surface. These devices, which look like small underwater microphones, are anchored to the bottom of the ocean using cables and large, heavy chunks of metal such as old train wheels.

highlights_secondary:
In 2019, Resolve partnered with technology companies to develop a security system called TrailGuard AI. When developing TrailGuard, engineers trained the computer vision system with a dataset that included hundreds of thousands of images of people and animals. The images used were captured from many angles and included a wide range of poses, like people and animals running or walking. After training TrailGuard with these images, engineers were then able to program the system to distinguish between animals and potential poachers.

To improve its accuracy, engineers continually update the system’s dataset with more images. This process of continuous training helps ensure that the system is always improving and that it’s consistently increasing its ability to identify certain elements in an image.

highlights_secondary: Supporting one revolution also inadvertently led France into another: their own. As a result of the aid they gave to American revolutionaries, the French government accumulated a large amount of debt. Leaders tried, and failed, to raise taxes to cover these costs. The Catholic Church and many elite citizens paid very little in taxes; they had significant political power and wouldn't agree to pay more. Most peasants paid between one-third and one-half of their income in taxes; they couldn't afford to pay more. This inequality, combined with other problems like food shortages and rising prices, drove people to action. On July 14, 1789, a mob stormed the Bastille prison in Paris, sparking the French Revolution.

highlights_secondary: The American Revolution also gave France the opportunity to strengthen its economy while harming British trade. By supporting American colonists, France hoped to disrupt this system and open up new markets to buy raw materials and sell French goods.

highlights_secondary: The American Revolution also gave France the opportunity to strengthen its economy while harming British trade. highlights_secondary: While some missionaries were welcomed at first, this changed when the Tokugawa Shogunate, a new military government, came into power in the early 17th century. These shoguns had helped create a more united Japan after years of fighting, and they worried that the spread of Catholicism might lead to instability. One reason? 16th century Catholicism was not tolerant of other religions, and converts were required to reject different belief systems. By contrast, religious diversity was the norm in Japan: most people practiced Buddhism, Shintoism, or a combination of these and folk traditions. Additionally, the shogunate knew that some Catholic missionaries tried to influence politics. Tokugawa leaders relied on strictly-enforced hierarchies to maintain control—outside interference and worship of a higher power, they believed, might challenge these systems and encourage rebellion.

highlights_secondary: To the Tokugawa shoguns, the spread of Catholicism was a potential threat to their power outside of the country as well. From the 15th to the 17th centuries, during a period known as the Age of Exploration, European empires sent travelers around the world to collect gold, secure influence for their leaders, and spread Catholic Christianity. Tokugawa leaders saw how Catholic Spain had used religion to seize control of the Philippines, a trading partner to the south of Japan, in 1565. The shogunate worried that their country would face a similar fate if Catholicism were allowed to spread. They didn't want to become part of a European empire and lose their independence.

highlights_secondary: Healthy and unhealthy coral reefs produce different sounds. Healthy coral reefs have loud, crackling sounds similar to a campfire, while unhealthy reefs are quieter. "A healthy reef is full of lots of animals that all make noises at different times of day and for different reasons, and you can hear that," Timothy AC Lamont, a marine biologist, explained in an interview with the Linnean Society. "By contrast, a reef that is degraded will sound eerie and quiet. It's almost spooky." Listening to audio recordings of these underwater sounds helps scientists assess the well-being of the reefs and their inhabitants.

highlights_secondary: Healthy and unhealthy coral reefs produce different sounds. Healthy coral reefs have loud, crackling sounds similar to a campfire, while unhealthy reefs are quieter. "A healthy reef is full of lots of animals that all make noises at different times of day and for different reasons, and you can hear that," Timothy AC Lamont, a marine biologist, explained in an interview with the Linnean Society. "By contrast, a reef that is degraded will sound eerie and quiet. It's almost spooky." Listening to audio recordings of these underwater sounds helps scientists assess the well-being of the reefs and their inhabitants.

In 2023, for example, scientists developed technology that can release different smells by heating and cooling scented wax. highlights_secondary: Smell is the only sense that is directly connected to the parts of the brain that process emotions and create memories. highlights_secondary:
Although they had been given a seat at the table in Paris, Japan’s leaders were concerned that they might not have equal say in conversations there. Japanese citizens continued to experience discrimination in many places around the world, and officials believed they might be similarly mistreated in the League of Nations.

|

To solve this problem, Japanese representatives proposed that the Treaty of Versailles should include a short additional clause called the Racial Equality Proposal. This clause asked all members of the League of Nations to give "equal and just treatment in every respect making no distinction, either in law or in fact, on account of their race or nationality." This language, Japanese leaders hoped, would protect their new global power and ensure they were respected in the League of Nations.

highlights_secondary:
Indigenous communities knew that the best way to preserve the rainforest for future generations was to plant more native trees from the seeds of trees already flourishing in the region. In 2007, representatives from the 24 Indigenous tribes in the region, including the Ikpeng and the Kamayurá, came together with local farmers and community organizations. Together, they founded Rede de Sementes do Xingu, or the Xingu Seed Network.

|

The seeds are planted by an Indigenous-led restoration campaign called Y Ikatu Xingu, which helps reforest the area. Since it was founded, the Xingu Seed Network has helped reforest more than 15,000 acres of land.

|

Today, the network includes over 560 seed collectors, mostly women, who gather seeds from native species to help reforest the Amazon. The seed collectors use their expertise to choose seeds that are genetically varied and resilient to climate change.

sample_entry: the water quality from the Xingu river is getting worse because of the tribe.
feedback_primary: That's true! Now be more specific. Who is threatening the Amazon?
feedback_secondary: Keep revising! Try to be even more specific. Which group is causing problems for the Amazon? Read the highlighted text for ideas.
highlights_secondary:
As deforestation progressed, Indigenous people living along the Xingu River in the Amazon noticed that the water quality was getting worse. Chemicals used in farming and other pollutants from deforestation were contaminating the once-clean river. This meant that the river no longer provided Indigenous communities with reliably clean water.

|

But the Amazon is under threat. In the late 20th century, the Brazilian government helped establish large farms and cattle ranches in the Amazon to export soy, beef, and other products all over the world. As international demand for soy and beef grows, trees are cleared from the Amazon to make room for farms. Due to this deforestation, over 15 percent of the rainforest has already been lost.

highlights_secondary: The Amazon rainforest is the world's largest tropical rainforest. It spans Brazil and seven other South American countries. For thousands of years, the Amazon has been home to about 400 Indigenous tribes, including the Ikpeng. These communities rely on the rainforest for their livelihood. As Magaró Ikpeng, one of the leaders of the Yarang Women's Movement, told Instituto Socioambiental, "The forest offers shelter, a garden, hunting." The Xingu River in the Amazon also provides a source of clean water for drinking, bathing, and fishing.

highlights_secondary: In the 1800s, commercial whaling, the practice of hunting and killing whales for profit, took off. Whalers from across the globe increasingly hunted bowheads for oil and other raw materials that they could sell (often discarding the parts of the carcass that they didn’t see as valuable). Before commercial whaling began, approximately 20,000 bowheads swam in the Western Arctic. By 1914, there were so few bowheads left in the Western Arctic that commercial whalers stopped hunting bowheads there altogether.

highlights_secondary: Bowhead whaling is central to Inupiat culture: numerous values and community traditions are rooted in the hunting, harvesting, and sharing of bowhead whales, which they use for both food and building materials. The Inupiat believe that the whales are sacred and choose to offer their lives to their people for sustenance. In return, the Inupiat offer a prayer of thanks during events such as Nalukataq and are careful to use every part of the whale, including the skin, meat, blubber, and bones.

highlights_secondary:
One of the main benefits of surgical robots is their precision. Surgical robots can perform delicate movements with very little error. The robots also filter out tremors, or shaking, in the doctor's hands, which lowers the chance of unintentional nicks or cuts during the operation.
Robotic surgeries are usually minimally invasive. This means that surgeons make tiny cuts, rather than the large incisions used in traditional open surgery. As Dr. Greg Farwell explained in an interview with UC Davis Health, "[Surgical robots] allow us to get to parts of the body with smaller or fewer incisions." This, he says, can speed up the healing process and improve the patient's recovery overall.

highlights_secondary:
Altering official records of history, like photographs, was one way that Stalin built this cult of personality. This practice allowed him to control the image of himself presented to the public. It also let him rewrite history in ways that were more favorable to him. For example, he could pretend that he had played a bigger role in the Russian Revolution than he really had, or he could make it look like people who opposed him had never existed.

highlights_secondary: But these economic policies directly impacted revolutionaries' day-to-day lives too. For the wealthy, taxation threatened their growing profits and power. For poorer people, the situation was far more urgent. Taxes raised costs and this, combined with food shortages and low wages, threatened their survival. Put simply: when people can’t get food for their families, they’re much more likely to take bold steps to fight for change.

highlights_secondary: Enlightenment ideas also led many to rethink the purpose of government and the source of its power. Throughout Europe, most people lived as the subject of kings and had little influence on the government. Monarchs claimed their status and authority was the will of a higher power, or a "divine right." Locke and others challenged this notion. They claimed that governments are created to protect natural rights, and the right to lead comes from the consent (permission) of the governed. This inspired revolutionaries to fight for a new approach to government later called popular sovereignty, where the will of the people ruled.

highlights_secondary: One reason why brands rely on sponsored content is that many people trust the influencers they follow. That trust allows sponsored influencer content to harness the testimonial technique. The testimonial technique is a powerful device used in everything from advertising to propaganda. When a respected or famous individual endorses something, they lend their credibility to that thing—even if they lack expertise. A TikTok influencer might be qualified to tell their followers whether a drink tastes good, for example, but they probably aren’t qualified to determine its health benefits. If someone trusts that influencer, though, they may believe those health claims and want to buy the product.

highlights_secondary: Why do dogs like Shiloh have such a good sense of smell compared to people? One reason is that humans have about 6 million olfactory receptors that detect smell in their nose, while dogs have about 125 to 300 million, depending on the breed. In addition to having a lot of scent receptors, dogs also have a large olfactory bulb (the area of the brain that processes smell). In fact, a dog's olfactory bulb is about 40 times larger than a human's, relative to their respective brain sizes.

highlights_secondary:
It's impossible to say whether BeReal will remain popular, but Mariah Macias, a junior at Pepperdine University, feels optimistic about the app's future: “I feel like it’ll continue to stay decently popular for a good amount of time,” Macias told the student paper. “I don’t really see it dying out because I feel like most people are pretty consistent about doing it. And there’s such a big community of people doing it—let’s be real together.”

|

Though BeReal may offer upsides and downsides to its users, there is no doubt that the app has had a huge impact. In fact, the amount of people who use the app each month grew over 315% from 2021 to 2022.

highlights_secondary:
“In all honesty, I tend to wait until I’m in a scenic or cool location,” said New York City dog walker Macartney MacDonald, who has been using BeReal since June 2022, in a Huffington Post article. “And I try to make sure that I at least look decent.”

|

Others, like the writer Emily Bootle, argue that it's impossible to be truly authentic on social media. She claims that many people who use the app are still presenting carefully curated versions of themselves. Instead of pretending to have glamorous, exciting lives, however, they are pretending to be authentic. “If ‘realness’ is performed by 53 million people every day,” Bootle writes in an article for the New Statesman, “it becomes […] ‘inauthentic’.”

|

Some aren’t sold on the new app’s promise of authenticity. One reason is because, even though the app encourages users to post within the first two minutes, it’s possible to post later on when you’re doing something more interesting. The post will simply be labeled as “late.”

“In all honesty, I tend to wait until I’m in a scenic or cool location,” said New York City dog walker Macartney MacDonald, who has been using BeReal since June 2022, in a Huffington Post article. “And I try to make sure that I at least look decent.”

|

Others, like the writer Emily Bootle, argue that it's impossible to be truly authentic on social media. She claims that many people who use the app are still presenting carefully curated versions of themselves. Instead of pretending to have glamorous, exciting lives, however, they are pretending to be authentic. “If ‘realness’ is performed by 53 million people every day,” Bootle writes in an article for the New Statesman, “it becomes […] ‘inauthentic’.”

|

Some aren’t sold on the new app’s promise of authenticity. One reason is because, even though the app encourages users to post within the first two minutes, it’s possible to post later on when you’re doing something more interesting. The post will simply be labeled as “late.”

highlights_secondary:
Each new policy led to more protests. In part, this resulted from colonists’ beliefs that the laws threatened their growing wealth. Rural planters and urban merchants alike wanted to be able to buy and sell goods at the best prices. However, the British government controlled these prices and limited the colonists’ trading partners. Colonists also had to pay taxes on imports and exports, and new taxes raised the cost of everyday goods like sugar and tea.

|

Revolutionary leaders claimed that the new laws were being passed without their consent, since there were no colonial representatives in the British Parliament. Without this consent, they argued, the taxes and trade rules unfairly limited their natural rights.

James Otis Jr., a Massachusetts lawyer and political activist, famously summed up these concerns in the phrase that became a rallying cry for revolutionary leaders: "Taxation without representation is tyranny."

highlights_secondary:
Each new policy led to more protests. In part, this resulted from colonists’ beliefs that the laws threatened their growing wealth. Rural planters and urban merchants alike wanted to be able to buy and sell goods at the best prices. However, the British government controlled these prices and limited the colonists’ trading partners. Colonists also had to pay taxes on imports and exports, and new taxes raised the cost of everyday goods like sugar and tea.

|

Revolutionary leaders claimed that the new laws were being passed without their consent, since there were no colonial representatives in the British Parliament. Without this consent, they argued, the taxes and trade rules unfairly limited their natural rights.

James Otis Jr., a Massachusetts lawyer and political activist, famously summed up these concerns in the phrase that became a rallying cry for revolutionary leaders: "Taxation without representation is tyranny."

highlights_secondary:
But European potters were also creating something new. These pieces, known as Delftware, were a unique combination of Chinese and Dutch designs. Potters painted scenes of life in the Dutch countryside, such as windmills, country landscapes, or farmers caring for their animals or crops. These were painted next to Chinese decorations and patterns.

|

In response to these restrictions and limitations, European potters began to make their own versions of the Chinese porcelain to sell to European collectors. The city of Delft in the Netherlands quickly became one of the centers of European pottery production. Potters had not yet discovered how to reproduce the color and properties of Chinese porcelain. Instead, they used a clay that turned yellow when it was fired and then dipped the pieces in a white tin glaze to mimic the white of the Chinese porcelain. They also developed their own techniques for reproducing the bright blue designs and the shiny surface that they admired in the Chinese pieces.

highlights_secondary:
In order to address the potential danger from PHOs, NASA began working on a planetary defense mission called the Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART). The mission was simple: figure out if launching a spacecraft into an asteroid fast enough can change its trajectory. If the strategy works, then astronomers might one day be able to use it to defend the earth from a PHO.

|

Most PHOs are thought to have an extremely low likelihood of coming into contact with the earth, but they have the potential to do serious damage if they were to strike. In 2013, for example, a 55-66 foot asteroid impacted Chelyabinsk, Russia, injuring approximately 1,500 people and damaging more than 7,000 buildings. A larger one could level cities, damage entire regions, or, in a worst case scenario, cause another mass extinction event like the one that is believed to have wiped out most dinosaur species.

highlights_secondary: While oxpeckers sounding their alarm could potentially help black rhinos, the birds themselves pose a slight threat to the large animals. Oxpeckers’ main purpose for riding along the backs of large mammals, like black rhinos, is to feast on the bugs, like ticks, found on their skin and in their fur. These birds, though, can sometimes take their feeding too far. Oxpeckers can occasionally peck at and eat the flesh and scabs surrounding any wounds the large mammals may have. By doing this, the birds can actually hurt the black rhinos and prevent their wounds from healing.

highlights_secondary:
Great Britain, however, refuses to return the sculptures to Greece. The British government believes that the sculptures were legally removed from Greece and that Lord Elgin was protecting the pieces by removing them from the Parthenon. Specifically, he claimed that the Turks had been grinding down the sculptures to make cement. The director of the British Museum Neil MacGregor wrote, "Elgin believed he was rescuing the sculptures from the risk of further damage."

|

The British Museum also argues that more people would be able to appreciate these breathtaking sculptures if they remained at the museum. Each year, far fewer people visit the Parthenon than the British Museum, so sending the sculptures back to Greece would make them less accessible to the public.

In order to help protect Pompeii from further damage, the site was included in the World Monuments Watch list by the World Monuments Fund in 1996. The organization claimed that the site was in disrepair, and they advocated for the creation of a plan to restore the city. In the late 1990s, the Superintendent of Pompeii, Pietro Guzzo, stopped all new excavations at the site in order to focus on restoring the existing buildings.

|

Two years after the collapse of the House of the Gladiators, the Italian government initiated the Great Pompeii Project. The goal of the more than $100 million project is to address the ongoing conservation and restoration concerns at the site. Although more is needed to fully restore Pompeii, this project includes protecting the buildings from weather and water damage, securing foundations and walls, and restoring the frescos.

highlights_secondary:
In order to help protect Pompeii from further damage, the site was included in the World Monuments Watch list by the World Monuments Fund in 1996. The organization claimed that the site was in disrepair, and they advocated for the creation of a plan to restore the city. In the late 1990s, the Superintendent of Pompeii, Pietro Guzzo, stopped all new excavations at the site in order to focus on restoring the existing buildings.

|

Two years after the collapse of the House of the Gladiators, the Italian government initiated the Great Pompeii Project. The goal of the more than $100 million project is to address the ongoing conservation and restoration concerns at the site. Although more is needed to fully restore Pompeii, this project includes protecting the buildings from weather and water damage, securing foundations and walls, and restoring the frescos.

highlights_secondary:
Pompeii has also been affected by tourists. Around 2.5 million people visit the city every year, and this heavy traffic wears away the surface of the roads. Visitors remove small sections of the buildings and mosaics to take home as souvenirs, and frescoes can be damaged when tourists brush up against them.

|

Unfortunately, these excavations often caused major problems. Immediately after being unearthed, the city’s frescoes and mosaics began to deteriorate since they were no longer protected from the damaging effects of light and oxygen. Other natural forces such as rain, humidity, and temperature soon weakened Pompeii’s ancient buildings and caused further deterioration to the frescoes and mosaics. Many of these buildings were poorly rebuilt with inappropriate materials and were difficult to maintain.

New Mexico Tech, for example, raised their tuition by 9%, stating that the scholarship was a factor in this decision.

highlights_secondary:
In recent years, New Mexico has faced a significant decline in college enrollment. In fact, from 2010 to 2020, enrollment in the state dropped by 27%. Experts think this is due, in part, to the prohibitive cost of attending college.

|

The state has also been facing workforce shortages. A University of New Mexico study found in 2020 that the state was short 6,200 nurses, and teachers were in short supply as well. Many organizers and legislators believed that there was only one way to solve this problem: by making education more affordable so that more people could earn their degrees and enter these fields.

highlights_secondary: As a result of gender inequality, early modern women usually lacked financial independence. Any money that a married woman earned or inherited automatically belonged to her husband. Laws also prevented married women from purchasing or owning property. Women’s job options were limited too. Wealthier women were mostly expected to manage their households and support their husband’s work, while poorer women often held labor-intensive and low-paying jobs, like working as servants or manufacturing textiles and other goods.

highlights_secondary:
Just like real-life women, many female characters, including those in Shakespeare’s plays, were independent, ambitious, and sometimes even rebellious. In Romeo and Juliet, for example, Juliet goes against her father, who expects her to marry the wealthy Paris. Instead, she secretly marries Romeo, the boy she really loves. By defying her father and making her own choice about marriage, Juliet asserts her agency and independence.
Juliet’s decision not to marry Paris and stay true to her secret husband Romeo is what sets the ending of the play into motion. Rather than taking on the passive role that was expected of women and girls, Juliet makes a decision so big that it impacts every other character in the play: Paris is left wifeless, Juliet and Romeo die, and ultimately two warring families reconcile their age-old feud.

highlights_secondary: Gender inequality was widespread in early modern England. One reason for this gender inequality was the strong influence of patriarchal values. Patriarchal values are a set of beliefs that prioritize men’s authority over women. In this worldview, men were seen as superior to women and were expected to hold power over them. These beliefs were not just personal opinions; they were deeply embedded in various aspects of society in early modern England. The legal system, for instance, granted men significant advantages over women, making it easier for them to maintain power and control. Additionally, religious leaders often taught that women were inferior to men, which further contributed to inequality between the genders.

highlights_secondary:
With a secret love affair dominating its plot, Romeo and Juliet is considered a romance or love story by many readers and critics—despite its ultimately tragic ending. The beginning of the play is all about the young couple’s whirlwind relationship and secret marriage. Juliet and Romeo exchange romantic speeches that establish the intensity and power of their love. “Juliet is the sun,” Romeo reflects, for she brightens his days and is at the center of his life. And Juliet compares her love for Romeo to the ocean: deep and limitless. “​​My bounty is as boundless as the sea, / My love as deep,” she tells him. “[T]he more I give to thee, / The more I have, for both are infinite.”
But in the second half of the play, the story takes a tragic turn. When Juliet’s cousin accidentally stabs Romeo’s friend, Romeo kills the cousin in anger and is banished from the city. Lovesick Juliet hatches a plan to reunite with her new husband against her family’s wishes: she takes a sleeping potion that will make her appear dead, and her beloved Romeo will come rescue her.

highlights_secondary:
Nevertheless, many critics believe that college application essay requirements can be improved. One suggestion is to change the kind of writing that students are asked to share: students could submit classwork instead of essays, for example. This may help limit plagiarism and lead to writing samples that better reflect academic ability.

|

Others argue for bigger changes, like making personal essays optional or getting rid of them entirely. Alternatively, reviewers could receive extra training on avoiding bias and identifying important character traits in essays.

highlights_secondary:
Essays also let students provide useful context, or background information, for other parts of their application. If someone had responsibilities that made it hard to join sports and clubs, for instance, they can explain that in an essay. Colleges and universities can then consider applicants holistically (as a whole) and better understand each student’s experiences.

|

Some advocates believe that personal essays benefit students after they enroll, too. These essays can help admissions offices identify those who need extra writing instruction, helping to ensure students have the support they need to successfully earn a degree.

|

Supporters argue that essays make college applications fairer by sharing personal and academic strengths more clearly and completely. Students can use an essay to highlight achievements and skills—including artistic talents, special awards, and volunteer work—that aren’t shown on a transcript.

Moreover, tutors may heavily revise or even fully rewrite student essays. This, opponents argue, is another problem: not all personal essays are written by students themselves, and schools can’t always tell when applicants submit someone else’s work.

|

On the other hand, critics claim that personal essays actually make college applications more unfair. One reason? Students from wealthy households are more likely to attend well-funded schools with strong writing instruction. Additionally, they often have access to extra writing help, including professional support from private tutors. With some costing $150 or more per hour, these kinds of services are often unaffordable for lower-income families.

Some also note that holistic applications have been used to discriminate. What is one of the achievements that makes people think Simone Biles is one of the great gymnasts of all time? Read the highlighted text for ideas.
highlights_secondary:
After being noticed for her natural talent, Simone Biles started officially training as a gymnast at just 8 years old. By 16, Biles became the first Black gymnast and the seventh American woman to earn the gold medal for being the “all-around” champion at the 2013 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships. Since her World Championships debut, Simone Biles has been named the all-around world champion at four additional competitions, earning a total of 25 world medals, including 19 gold. Upon earning her 25th medal, Biles broke the record of the most world medals earned by any gymnast.

In 2016, Simone Biles wowed many when she made her Summer Olympics debut on Team USA. She walked away with five Olympic medals (four gold and one bronze)—that’s when many began to consider her gymnastics’ G.O.A.T.

highlights_secondary: That’s what American writer Delia Bacon wondered. In the 1800s, she voiced a bold theory: Shakespeare was a fraud. Since then, various scholars, historians, and readers have argued that Shakespeare could not have actually written well-known plays like Romeo and Juliet, Hamlet, and Macbeth. Instead, they think that someone else wrote the plays, using Shakespeare’s name as a cover. Skeptics have suggested that the real author could have been a nobleman or famous philosopher too embarrassed to admit that he was writing plays on the side—or even another playwright who had to hide his true identity after faking his death. Altogether, Shakespeare skeptics have suggested over seventy possible candidates as the “true” author of Shakespeare’s plays.

highlights_secondary:
Not everyone supports including esports in the Olympics. Critics say that esports shouldn’t become an Olympic sport because they don’t require physical exertion, or effort, like most traditional sports. While it’s common for esports players to train for 10-12 hours a day, they usually don’t have to leave their seats to do so.
Leaders at the IOC are also concerned that some esports games are too violent. IOC President Thomas Bach, for example, has said that “[the IOC does not] want. . . anything to do with killer games. . .” This kind of content, he explained, doesn’t align with the Olympic values of promoting peace and respect.

While there are potential downsides to the #QuokkaSelfie, the social media trend has had positive effects as well. Thanks in part to the thousands of photos on social media, Rottnest Island’s tourism went up 30% from 2017 to 2018. highlights_secondary:
In order to help cheerleading become an official NCAA sport and hopefully be recognized by Title IX in the future, USA Cheer has started two initiatives. The first is that they created a new branch of cheerleading, called STUNT. This type of cheerleading focuses on the athletic and competitive aspects of the activity, and it was created with the purpose of meeting Title IX sport requirements.

|

Then, they applied for STUNT to be part of the NCAA's Emerging Sports for Women program. This program was created to help increase opportunities for women in sports. Acceptance into this program would put cheerleading on the path to become an official NCAA sport in the next ten years.

highlights_secondary:
U.S. District Court Judge Stefan R. Underhill explained in 2010 that the "activity is still too underdeveloped and disorganized to be treated as offering genuine varsity athletic participation opportunities for students." The NCAA (National Collegiate Athletic Association) has also not accepted cheerleading as an official sport, which means that cheerleaders do not have access to the NCAA scholarships that athletes in other sports receive.

|

While many people may consider cheerleading a sport, federal and district courts in the U.S. have ruled that cheerleading does not qualify as a sport under Title IX (pronounced title nine), which is a law that protects athletes from discrimination based on their sex.

highlights_secondary:
According to the Oxford Dictionary, a sport is "an activity involving physical exertion and skill… in which an individual or a team competes against another or others for entertainment." Cheerleading requires flexibility, strength, physical agility, endurance, and teamwork. In addition, cheerleading is highly competitive, with almost 1,400 teams competing in the 2022 NCA (National Cheerleaders Association) All Star National Championship.

|

Some people may be fooled by the pom poms and encouraging cheers, but cheerleading requires substantial athletic ability and skill. "Flyers," who are lofted into the air by "bases," must have a combination of agility, balance, and strength, and bases need extreme strength and endurance to hold up flyers. Because of the athleticism required, many people have argued that cheerleading should be recognized as an official sport.

In addition, cheerleading is highly competitive, with almost 1,400 teams competing in the 2022 NCA (National Cheerleaders Association) All Star National Championship.

|

Some people may be fooled by the pom poms and encouraging cheers, but cheerleading requires substantial athletic ability and skill. "Flyers," who are lofted into the air by "bases," must have a combination of agility, balance, and strength, and bases need extreme strength and endurance to hold up flyers. Because of the athleticism required, many people have argued that cheerleading should be recognized as an official sport.

highlights_secondary: In October 2020, France passed a new law to protect kidfluencers. The law provides them with the same rights as child actors and models in France. It limits work hours, requires earnings to be put into a bank account that the child can access when they turn 16, and ensures a “right to be forgotten,” meaning that social media platforms must take down content at the child’s request. Advocates hope that the French law inspires similar laws in the U.S. and around the world.

highlights_secondary:
Not everyone thinks that kidfluencer laws are necessary. Some parents of kidfluencers argue that their children are playing, not working. It’s the parents who are responsible for organizing photoshoots, communicating with brands, posting and scheduling content, and more. “Our children don't work, we do,” Ami McClure, the mother of kidfluencer twins who have 2.3 million Instagram followers, writes on her blog. “They goof around on camera maybe fifteen minutes a few times a week. They're just being themselves, not memorizing lines.”

Opponents of kidfluencer laws also say that work conditions would be difficult to enforce. While child actors work in studios or theaters, kidfluencers are often filmed in the privacy of their homes, where monitoring their hours could be impractical and invasive.

highlights_secondary:
Advocates are concerned that kidfluencers are at risk of being exploited by their parents for financial gain. YouTube and Instagram don’t let individuals have an account unless they’re 13 years or older, so most kidfluencer accounts are owned and managed by their guardians. This means that any earnings from these accounts goes straight to the parents, who then have control over whether money is set aside for their children.

Supporters of kidfluencer laws also argue that without proper regulation, young influencers could be working too many hours a day. As Byron Austen Ashley, the manager of several kidfluencers, told The Hollywood Reporter: “If [parents] are using [the child’s earnings] for personal reasons, that amplifies the risk of them planning 10-hour workdays, rather than structured, comfortable workdays.”

As Byron Austen Ashley, the manager of several kidfluencers, told The Hollywood Reporter: “If [parents] are using [the child’s earnings] for personal reasons, that amplifies the risk of them planning 10-hour workdays, rather than structured, comfortable workdays.”

highlights_secondary:
In the United States, children who work in the entertainment industry have laws to protect them. Since 1939, Coogan’s Law—named for child actor Jackie Coogan, whose parents spent almost his entire fortune—safeguards the earnings of young performers. There are also laws in some states that restrict how many hours a child performer can work. However, these laws are currently limited to the traditional entertainment industry and don’t apply to kidfluencers.

Advocates are concerned that kidfluencers are at risk of being exploited by their parents for financial gain. YouTube and Instagram don’t let individuals have an account unless they’re 13 years or older, so most kidfluencer accounts are owned and managed by their guardians. This means that any earnings from these accounts goes straight to the parents, who then have control over whether money is set aside for their children.

Supporters of kidfluencer laws also argue that without proper regulation, young influencers could be working too many hours a day. As Byron Austen Ashley, the manager of several kidfluencers, told The Hollywood Reporter: “If [parents] are using [the child’s earnings] for personal reasons, that amplifies the risk of them planning 10-hour workdays, rather than structured, comfortable workdays.”

highlights_secondary: Australia was struggling with voter turnout in the 1920s, so they passed an act that made voting mandatory. When only a small percentage of a country’s population votes, the election results don’t necessarily reflect the opinions of the country as a whole. In turn, elected officials may make decisions that inaccurately represent the needs of the citizens who elected them. Therefore, high voter turnout tends to lead to election results that more accurately reflect what the citizens want.

highlights_secondary:
The act increased schools’ funding to pay for the new, healthier meals. However, some schools still do not receive enough money to cover the cost of these meals. To fill this money gap, about 87% of schools sell food items that are known as Smart Snacks.

At Manchester schools, this was not possible: hats, hoodies, bonnets, and durags were banned.

Talk about what some minor league baseball players did as a result of believing their salaries are unfair. Read the highlighted text for ideas.
highlights_secondary:
In 2014, a group of minor league players filed a class-action lawsuit against MLB over their low wages. Since then, the case has expanded to include thousands of players who were not paid for spring training or made salaries below the poverty line. They want back pay and rules to pay players for hours worked.

"The ultimate goal is pretty simple: to get MLB to comply with the same laws that Walmart and McDonald's comply with," Garrett Broshuis, a lawyer and former minor league player who filed the original lawsuit, told ESPN.

After facing several hurdles making its way through the courts, a trial is set for 2022. The lawsuit could have major consequences for the future of Minor League Baseball.

Talk about how governments are responding to the debate around plastic bag reduction laws. Use the highlighted text for ideas.
highlights_secondary:
Many governments agree that, despite their drawbacks, plastic bag reduction laws help the environment. As a result, governments are working to address the potential negative consequences of these laws. Some governments are funding training programs to help plastic workers transition to renewable energy jobs. Others are providing low-income residents with free, reusable shopping bags.

As of 2021, nine states have banned single-use plastic bags: California, Oregon, New York, Vermont, Maine, Connecticut, Delaware, Washington, and New Jersey. Hundreds of cities and towns have passed their own plastic bag reduction laws as well.

Other states and cities are considering a ban or tax on plastic bags. Are the environmental benefits of plastic bag reduction laws worth the economic cost of changing how people shop?

sample_entry: companies are working to grow it to help reduce the amount of methane cows burp.
feedback_primary: That's true! Now be more specific. How widespread are the efforts to grow seaweed?
feedback_secondary: Keep revising! Try to be even more specific. How widespread are the efforts to grow enough seaweed to reduce cows' methane emissions? Read the highlighted text for ideas.
highlights_secondary:
Before this research began, Asparagopsis was only found in oceans around the globe and divers had to gather it by hand. There are now companies around the world that are working to grow it to help reduce cows’ methane emissions.

Some companies, like Blue Ocean Barns in Hawaii, have begun to grow this seaweed on land in large seawater tanks, while other companies, such as Sea Forest in Tasmania, Australia, have begun to grow it on large ropes in the ocean.

It will take a global effort to cultivate, or grow, enough Asparagopsis to reduce cows’ methane emissions. But as Joan Salwen, the CEO of Blue Oceans Barns, recently stated: “Cultivation has been the biggest question mark and stumbling block and [now] it actually is in our grasp. And that is so exciting.”

sample_entry: it is not yet a solid solution for the problem.
feedback_primary: That's true! Now be more specific. Why is this not yet a solid solution?
feedback_secondary: Keep revising! Try to be even more specific. Why is using seaweed to reduce cows' methane emissions not yet a solid solution? Read the highlighted text for ideas.
highlights_secondary:
Feeding cows seaweed could reduce about one-third of greenhouse gas emissions produced by livestock. However, it is not yet a solid solution for the problem.

There is currently not enough Asparagopsis seaweed available to feed all of the cows around the world. According to research, Asparagopsis only needs to make up about 1% of cows’ daily diets in order to lower methane emissions. Though that is a small amount, there are still around 1.5 billion cows on the planet releasing methane gas with each burp. For this solution to work, more of this seaweed would need to be grown globally.

highlights_secondary: Ever since Dolly was born, the cloning industry has slowly expanded. It has become fairly common practice for livestock breeders to clone farm animals. For example, farmers can choose to clone the cow, sheep, or pig that gains weight the fastest, consistently gets pregnant on the first try, or stays the healthiest. Through cloning, farmers can improve the quality of their livestock and ultimately increase profits. Pet owners can also pay for their cats and dogs to be cloned—Barbara Streisand, a famous singer, had her beloved dog cloned so that she wouldn’t feel like she lost her dog when it died.

highlights_secondary:
Building on decades of research, Ian Wilmut experimented with the nucleus of a cell, which is the part that contains DNA. A clone has the same DNA as the original animal, so Wilmut had to figure out how to transfer DNA from one cell to another.

|

To create Dolly, Wilmut took skin cells from the sheep he wanted to clone. Then, he took an egg from a different female sheep. This egg already contained a nucleus with its own DNA, but Wilmut wanted it to have the DNA of the sheep he was cloning. In order to do that, he replaced the egg’s nucleus with a nucleus from the original sheep's skin cells. Then, he placed that new cell into another female sheep, who became pregnant with the clone, Dolly.
